texts.title: A Treatise of Human Nature
texts.sourceDesc: The first two Books of Hume’s <cite>Treatise of Human Nature</cite> were published together in 1739. The third Book, which included an Appendix making some changes to Book 1, was published in 1740. There was only one edition published in Hume’s lifetime, an this edition is therefore our copytext.

texts.title: An Abstract of a Book Lately Published
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s <cite>Abstract</cite> of his own <cite>Treatise</cite> was published in 1740. Our copytext is that sole edition.

texts.title: Essays, Withdrawn and Unpublished
texts.sourceDesc: The first edition of Hume’s <cite>Essays, Moral and Political</cite> contained eight essays that were later withdrawn from the <cite>Essays, Moral, Political, and Literary, Part 1</cite> (as this collection would ultimately be called). These essays are collected together here, alongside the two unpublished essays <cite>Of Suicide</cite> and <cite>Of the Immortality of the Soul</cite>. These latter were printed in 1755, intended for what became the <cite>Four Dissertations</cite> of 1757, but Hume soon regretted the decision and had them removed, writing the essay <cite>Of the Standard of Taste</cite> to fill their place. A few copies of the 1755 print were circulated (against Hume’s wishes), which therefore serves as our copytext. In preparing the critical text here, the copy held in the National Library of Scotland, containing several modifications in Hume’s hand, was consulted.

texts.title: A Letter from a Gentleman to His Friend in Edinburgh
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s <cite>Letter to a Gentleman</cite> was published in 1745. Our copytext is this sole original edition.

texts.title: Essays and Treatises on Several Subjects
texts.sourceDesc: The first more or less complete edition of Hume’s <cite>Essays and Treatises on Several Subjects</cite>, his collected philosophical works, was published in 1758, although each of its component works were published separately before then, and an incomplete version (predating the <cite>Four Dissertations</cite>) was published in 1753. Our copytext is the posthumous edition of 1777, which Hume was working on before he died, and which contains many final alterations.

texts.title: The History of England
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s <cite>History of England</cite> was written in three stages, and in reverse chronological order. He began with two volumes on the History of Great Britain (from the Union of the Crowns to the death of James II), published in 1754 and 1757. In 1759 he then published two more volumes, on the House of Tudor. This necessitated changing the title from the <cite>History of Great Britain</cite> to the <cite>History of England</cite>, since he now began the story a century and a half before the union. Finally, in 1762, he published two more volumes tracing the country’s history back even further, all the way to the Celtic Britons and the Roman invasion. In 1763, the first complete set was published, but owing to the size of the work – including the now very large index included in the final volume – it had to be chopped up rather awkwardly into 8 volumes rather than 6. The text here follows the posthumous 1778 edition, which Hume was working on before he died. That edition was also (of necessity) printed in 8 volumes, but it is shown here divided into 6 volumes instead (matching the breaks that appeared in the volumes as they were originally published).

texts.title: My Own Life
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s short autobiographical <cite>My Own Life</cite> was published in 1777, coinciding with the posthumous edition of his <cite>Essays and Treatises</cite>. Our copytext is this first edition.

texts.title: Dialogues concerning Natural Religion
texts.sourceDesc: Hume began work on his <cite>Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion</cite> in the 1750s. Because of the sensitive nature of the text, however, he did not publish it in his lifetime, but left instructions to his nephew to publish it after his death. It was printed in 1779, and this edition is naturally our copytext. Fortunately, however, Hume’s own manuscript for the work survives. This manuscript was consulted in drawing up the critical text provided here.
